d:abstract.d:para: These are the criteria by which I grade a book. A grade of 1 usually means that I have made a definite decision not to finish a book. Of course, there are some books that I start and set aside. But I only enter the book if I have finished it or determined it is not worth finishing.

d:simplelist.d:member: 4 - Can recommend the book to others
5 - Intend to read the book again

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stacy gave this book to me for Christmas, and just like in 2009, I started the year off with a book about the Navy. One of my favorite books about the Civil War was The Warrior Generals by Commander Thomas Buell (ret.) It was a thought provoking examination of four generals, two Union and two Confederate. And it was a delight to read. Perhaps more to be expected by a retired Naval officer turned historian, this is the biography of Admiral Raymond Spruance, a man of towering accomplishment who is generally overshadowed by the more flamboyant figures of WWII. But CDR Buell's writing is just as clear and compelling in this book as it was in The Warrior Generals. It is difficult to pinpoint just what it is about his style that I find so compelling. As a career Naval Officer, he has an insider's view into Admiral Spruance's career, yet I believe this book would be as accessible to a civilian as it is to a former Naval Officer. He evaluates Adm Spruance's actions with a professional eye, and provides judgement on any controversial actions or decisions in just a few well crafted sentences.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: John Henry Cardinal Newman's account of his conversion to the Catholic Church. The style is very dry and cerebral; and Cardinal Newman seems sensitive to charges that he had been less than forthright in his days as an Anglican priest. In contemporary America, with its celebration of the supremacy of the individual and emphasis on the individual's relationship with God, this tone seems defensive. But in early Victorian Britain, with its ingrained prejudice against Catholicism and belief in English superiority, the tone is perhaps more understandable. Indeed, Cardinal Newman retains his British sense of upright behavior, refusing to proselytize for the Catholic faith. Rather he gives an honest account of how, through his research into the teachings of the Church fathers, he came to view the Anglican Church as heretical. This account really may only appeal to a serious theologian. Where his account is of interest to a broader audience is in his criticism of the "Liberal" party in the Anglican Church and the danger of the liberal promotion of personal behavior and rejection of dogma. Given the current state of the Anglican Church, Cardinal Newman's warnings seem to be confirmed.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Lieutenant Commander John Owen was the team Chaplain for the Navy Football team for the 2007 season. The book is really a collection of his pre-game talks to the team combined with his reflections on his role as a religious teacher in a secular institution. Personally, the talks aren't interesting. What is interesting are the inside observations of the players and coaches who participated in one of the best season's in Navy football history.

d:title.d:emphasis: In the Aftermath: Provocations and Lamentations

d:simplesect.para: An engaging and stimulating collection of essays by a contemporary Orthodox theologian. I found his essay regarding Pope John Paul II's outreach to the Orthodox church to be particularly insightful. Mr. Hart is a formidable opponent of secular materialists and militant Darwinists. This can make for delightfully entertaining passages. In this season of Lent, I wonder whether to admire his spirited defense of Christianity or blush at his refusal to turn the other cheek to his enemies. While this observation is made somewhat light-heartedly, it is a point to ponder. Christian humility certainly does not preclude a spirited defense or promotion of Christianity. But when the tone descends to the level of squabbling academics, has a line between humility and pride been traversed? But the reading was entertaining enough that I won't take him to task too severely. Reading these essays is also a great way to improve your vocabulary. Mr. Hart most assuredly does not believe in writing at a layman's level. Turning, at random to a single page (which happened to fall in the essay "The Laughter of the Philosophers") consisting of 38 lines, the following words provide an example of his formidable vocabulary: obtundently, perspicuous, caliginous, turgidity, splenetic

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: What Hath God Wrought: The Transformation of America, 1815-1848

d:simplesect.d:para: An edition of the Oxford History of the United States; the same series that includes James McPherson's Battle Cry of Freedom. Stephen Brumbaugh lent this book to me. A comprehensive examination of the military, political, religious, artistic and social history of the United States from the end of the War of 1812 to the end of the Mexican War. In some respects, a very balanced account with no revisionist economic or social theory to explain the events. He details both the great accomplishments and the glaring iniquities of the period. Perhaps the greatest strength of this book is coverage of the role that religion played in America during this period. Perhaps because my interest has always been more for military history, religion tends to be overlooked unless it is plainly unavoidable (such as in dealing with the Mormon migration to Utah). For example, in all the books by Bruce Catton, I don't remember any discussion on the religious influences or practices of either the Union or the Confederacy. Mr. Howe does a nice job in showing how religious beliefs and practices led to concrete social and political results.

However, there are some glaring weaknesses as well. While purporting to provide a narrative of the period, he never the less is not shy about passing judgement upon people and their actions. For example, during the Battle of New Orleans, the British commander assigned one of his Irish units the task of carrying bundles of brush to fill in the ditch in front of the American lines. For whatever reason, the commander of the Irish unit failed to make the arrangements and the subsequent British attack was badly hampered. The dereliction of this commander is self evident even to someone not versed in military history, and simply describing the situation allows anyone with any intelligence to draw the appropriate conclusion. But Mr. Howe still provides his personal judgement on the Irish commander's culpability. And the yardstick Mr. Howe uses to make his judgements is to compare are modern conventions of right and wrong. This shows him to fall in the "progressive" school of historians who view all history as a long development to the present "enlightened" time. In Mr. Howe's defense, this is probably the most typical outlook of modern historians. The problem with this approach is that many times the historian is quick to see the faults of his subject without evaluating how the virtues of the subject compare with the faults of the author and his society.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This is a very short work detailing how a single act of selfishness causes a chain of consequences. This serves as a useful vehicle for Tolstoy to examine some of the ignoble facets of the Russian society of his day. The chain of misfortunes, however, also spurs some positive actions, mostly by characters who share Tolstoy's personal view of Christianity and its place for social reform. The problem with Tolstoy's view of Christianity is that it is essentially a Protestant view in which the individual is capable of working out his relationship with Christ and that the Church is generally a hindrance to this process. But G.K. Chesterton offers a strong critique of this view: "My point is that the world did not tire of the Church's ideal, but of its reality. Monasteries were impugned not for the chastity of monks, but for the unchastity of monks. Christianity was unpopular not because of the humility, but the arrogance of Christians. Certainly if the church failed it was largely through the churchmen." In each and every age, the Church and society in general are composed of the saints, the ordinary and the wicked. In each age, the saints carry forward the holiness of the Church despite the wickedness of the bad and the indifference of the ordinary. When an individual, or a group decides to leave the Church on account of the bad and the indifference, they also leave behind the saints. When they start their own church (as the Lutherans, Anglicans, etc.) they wind up in the same boat, only with a smaller crew. And when eventually one or more individuals in the protesting church leaves on account of the bad and indifferent, then a cascading chain of splintering churches is the result. So while Tolstoy is certainly right to point out the shortcomings of the Orthodox Church in the last years of the Romanov dynasty, his complete rejection of the Church winds up illustrating the point that the road to hell is paved with good intentions. Surely Satan is aware of the military maxim "Divide and Conquer."

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This book probably should not receive a grade as it is a reference work (and I know the editor.) Bishop Fenwick grew up on what is now Samson's Harbor Farm, and Father Tancrell visited my father in researching this book. I had the pleasure of meeting Father Tancrell when he was assigned to the Dominican House in Washington DC. Any collection of letters does not provide narrative flow, but this a fascinating look at life in the early days of America.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I've not yet decided on how to grade this book. It is a short series of lectures by C.S. Lewis dealing with the effects of moral relativism in education and as such is certainly prescient. I think that I will read this again before deciding on a grade.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I picked this up as reading material for Lent, but it is really social commentary rather than spiritual. Chesterton had a gift of penetrating insight, whether the subject is religion or society - not for nothing is he known as the "Apostle of Common Sense."

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This book belonged to my grandfather (Thaddeus Krush) and I inherited it from Nanny. It was very interesting reading this book after having read Evan Thomas' Jones bio just two years ago. I went back to my review of Mr. Thomas' biography to ensure that it was rated lower than the grade I assigned to this one (and indeed, I had rated it lower). In a way, an entire essay could be devoted to the differences between these two books. But to be brief, ADM Morison's credentials as an historian, his passion for sailing and his experience as historian for the US Navy during World War II provide greater credibility than Mr. Thomas' background as a reporter (all-be-it a very successful reporter). Given that the material covered was almost identical, Adm. Morison's book was more interesting, more balanced and more insightful.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: How Robert E. Lee Lost the Civil War

d:simplesect.d:para: It is not uncommon now days to argue that General Lee has been over-rated by historians, and Mr. Bonekemper has made a bid to be the coup-de-grace to Lee's reputation. While not quite descending to the level of jeremiad, Mr. Bonekemper misses no chance to point out Gen. Lee's faults. This is somewhat a shame, because he does have some good points to make. In fact, there are a number of very telling arguments. First, that Lee was too aggressive - and he presents some interesting figures to back this up. The statistics that he cites demonstrate that Lee lost more soldiers than any General in the war, both in raw numbers and in percentage of his forces lost. His poor staff work and overly complex plans helped contribute to the heavy losses. Mr. Bonekemper also suggests that Lee learned to be very aggressive in the Mexican War, when muskets and cannon had much less range and accuracy - which is an argument that I have not heard before but is worth consideration. He suggests that Lee should have used his influence to end the war in 1864 to prevent unnecessary bloodshed. Lee's invasions of the North were fatally flawed because given the scope of his plans, he was going to have to march his army back south at the end of the campaign, regardless of what happened along the way, and leave the impression that he had been forced to retire. He completely neglected the rest of the confederacy to focus on Virginia - which is perhaps the argument that most closely supports the assertion in the title of the book. There are a number of flaws in Mr. Bonekemper's presentation. He argues with the gift of hindsight, as if his conclusions were as glaringly obvious then as they are now. He makes no effort to identify what Lee did right. Indeed, his book reads as the summation by the prosecution rather than a intellectual evaluation. His chronological narrative does not support his arguments particularly well - he would have been better off organizing the book around his chief arguments.

d:title.d:emphasis: "They Have Killed Papa Dead: The Road to Ford's Theatre, Abraham Lincoln's Murder, and the Rage for Vengeance"

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This is the second time that I have read this book; this time prompted by having read Bonekemper's "How Lee Lost the Civil War" and Buell's bio of Admiral Spruance. I can't quite put my finger on what makes his style so distinctive, but I find his books hard to put down. In addition to style, he brings a tremendous amount of common sense to military subjects based upon his own career in the Navy. Mr. Buell focuses his attention on three Generals from the Union (Grant, Thomas and Barlow) and three Confederate generals (Lee, Hood and Gordon). He is pretty hard on both Grant and Lee, both of whom fought with tenacity but not always with skill. Both were weak in staff work and logistics and their short comings prevented them from achieving better results. Mr. Buell is perhaps a little hard on Grant, going so far as to label his 1864 campaign in Virginia as a failure. But no matter the tactical setbacks he experienced, he never lost the initiative and by refusing to disengage from Lee, he was sure to win in the end. Like Mr. Bonekemper, Buell criticizes Lee's lavish expenditure of his soldiers lives, but he is a bit more understanding of Lee's grand design to win the war for the Confederacy. Lee's intention was to influence northern opinion by sapping the will of the Army of the Potomac to fight and the will of the northern public to endure the losses and humiliation - all while preventing the Union army from over running his native state. In the end, he was unsuccessful - not for lack of will but for opportunities lost due to poor intelligence, missing maps, poor staff work and the loss of his best generals and soldiers due to aggressive tactics. The next pair of generals are Thomas and Hood. Buell argues that Thomas was the outstanding general of the war because he lacked none of the shortcomings of Lee and Grant. In fact, his staff work, logistical planning and intelligence operations clearly foreshadowed modern American combined operations. He defends Thomas from the denigrating comments by Grant and Sherman that he was superb on defense but slow to attack. One short coming of Thomas, and Buell does admit this, was his inability to communicate effectively with Grant and Sherman, which ultimately reduced his effectiveness. Another criticism that Buell missed is that Thomas' approach to war ignored politics. While he recognized that the only way to defeat the Confederacy was to destroy the southern armies, he wasn't as sensitive to northern politics as were Grant and Sherman. Perhaps his disdain for politics led him to feel a certain amount of disdain for Grant and Sherman, who were both political operators as well as generals. Hood gets perhaps the shortest shrift in the book and only seems to serve as a foil to illustrate the ultimately superiority of the northern methods of waging war. Hood was superb as a brigade and even division commander, largely average in a short stint as a corps commander and an absolute disaster as an army commander. The final pair of generals are Barlow and Gordon. Gordon had a sterling career, steadily moving up the ranks due to aggressiveness in battle. Barlow too gradually rose up through the ranks, although not quite as high as Gordon. The big contrast between the two warriors was that Gordon never really adapted his tactics as the war progressed, whereas Barlow learned to transition from tightly massed formations to flexible skirmish lines which could take advantage of the terrain.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A short novel written from the point of view of a young radical. Perhaps not up to his best standards, but Dostoevsky has a skill for taking an individual aliened from society and treating them sympathetically. The end result is that he more clearly illustrates the negative consequences of how they choose to respond to their alienation than if he had written a polemical essay against the folly of the "modern" reaction against all aspects of "traditional" society. He very clearly illustrates how the moderns "throw the baby out with the bath water" in their reaction against the negative features of their society and their fellow man. The short story "The Dream of the Ridiculous Man" was interesting - it seems to be another aliened young man who has turned to nihilism, but instead has a vision that transforms his life. Instead of a nihilist raging against society, he is transformed into a prophet in the mold of St. Paul. Interestingly enough, his vision could very well have been the idea for C.S. Lewis' story Out of the Silent Planet and also seems to be reflected in the book I am currently reading - Walker Percy's Lost in the Cosmos. I wonder if this influence is direct (i.e. they are reflecting upon Dostoevsky's story) or indirect.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Well written and thought provoking. General Hooker had many things going for him - excellent logistics, planning, staff work and infantry organization. Lee had very little going for him, terrible logistics, a third of his army absent from the battle and the loss of his best General about half way through the battle. Yet Lee managed to win a spectacular but ultimately costly and inclusive victory. Hooker had bad luck, (getting wounded at a critical juncture of the battle, etc.), he badly mishandled his cavalry and artillery and perhaps no general in the Civil War received worse performance from his subordinates. He also divided his forces, allowing Lee to shift back and forth between both wings of his army. In the end, he was unable to overcome the mistakes. The irony is that 6 weeks later, George Meade fought exactly the type of battle that Hooker wanted to fight - allowing Lee to repeatedly attack his prepared positions at Gettysburg.

d:title.d:emphasis: Lost in the Cosmos - The Last Self-Help Book

d:simplesect.d:para: This book was quite a find - I had never heard of it until I listened to a recorded lecture by Peter Kreeft in which he compared this book with C.S. Lewis' The Abolition of Man. It is funny to think of someone, perhaps a science fiction fan or amateur astronomer, stumbling upon this book seeing the title and thinking, "hey, this might be for me." But the "Last Self-Help Book" is sub-title is quite ironic, and if this book is a self-help book for anyone, it would be for philosophers, artists and scientist. Actually, Mr. Percy's approach in this book is probably as close to the Socratic method as anything I have read. He defines some terms relating to semiotics (the study of symbols) and spends the rest of the book asking questions and suggesting "thought experiments." Perhaps the single, overarching question in the book is from the dust jacket - "Why is it possible to learn more in ten minutes about the Crab Nebula in Taurus, which is 6,000 light-years away, than you presently know about yourself, even though you've been stuck with yourself all your life?"

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: The second book in Lewis' Space Trilogy, this book has much less action than the first installment; indeed, much less action than one typically expects from the science fiction genre. Instead, this book is an extended reflection upon the fall of man in the Garden of Eden and a look forward to the end times foretold in the Book of Revelation. The scenes where Westin (or rather the demon possessing Weston) is trying to tempt the Queen of Perelandra is a very subtle, persistent and disturbing - one wishes for the action to proceed to escape the oppressive atmosphere. Yet Westin's blandishments are so familiar - one can think of many examples in the media, in academia, in advertising and pop-culture - in which we are constantly bombarded with these empty promises. This book definitely calls for a second reading to fully explore Mr. Lewis' arguments and symbols.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: It is interesting how different is each of the books that comprise Lewis' Space Trilogy. The first, Out of the Silent Planet, is probably closest to contemporary science fiction. Perelandra is an extended theological exploration and That Hideous Strength is almost closer to an action-adventure story. It is a fast-paced and gripping account of what happens when science loses connection to morality. As I read this book, I felt it would be a nice companion piece to Solzhenitsyn's The First Circle.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stacy gave me an electronic book reader for my birthday, and this is the first book that I have finished. It was an open-source edition, and the problem with this is that the OCR technology isn't perfect. But the imperfections aren't much of a problem and are a small price to pay in order to be able to read a book like this, which would be difficult to find in print.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Recorded book. I first read this book 15 years ago after reading A Soldier of the Great War. The story was gripping, but so fantastic that it was hard to know what to make of it. I was delighted to find this on CD at the library. Although Mr. Helprin is Jewish, when I first read this book I thought that it had a very "Roman Catholic" outlook. This book resembles nothing so much as an artistic interpretation of the coming of the Messiah and the Apocalypse. The writing is beautiful, the characters are noble.

d:title.d:emphasis: The Arians of the Fourth Century

d:simplesect.d:para: Read from an open source e-book. The quality of the scan wasn't great - in particular, it had great difficulty with the footnote on the bottom of the page, especially if they extended to the next page. The history of heresies suffer in comparison to military histories in that theological battles are waged by scholars and theologians over fine shades of meaning, yet this book shows the very great consequences caused by even fine shades of meaning. For in all human affairs, there seems to be a never ending struggle between those who seek the truth and thus seek maximum precision in their language and those who seek some earthly reward - usually power, sometimes money - who are willing to shade meanings to hide their true intentions. When Constantine became emperor of Rome and became interested in Christianity as a means of unifying his empire, the stakes in theological disputes were raised immensely. This is an excellent defense of the Catholic position against the Arians and an excellent example of why the pursuit of truth and the accurate use of language are so important. Also, a good treatment of the career of St. Athanasius is woven throughout the narrative - this will be of interest to Thomas some day..

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.para: This novel was recommended in a lecture I listened to by Peter Kreeft. A much more polished open source e-book that illustrates the great benefit of the open source movement in e-books. It is hard to describe this book - the story is set in a suburb of London - a new development surrounding an old hill-top estate with an ancient history. The plot revolves around a local stage production of a play by the poet who inhabits the old estate. The story tracks some residents on the path to heaven in contrast with others who are on the descent mentioned in the title. The language is often dense, time becomes non-linear and the boundary between the living and the dead becomes blurred - indeed the writing at times seems more free verse than prose, yet the book is still oddly compelling for all that. Here is an example of a particularly dense sentence:

"Much difficulty in finding what? in finding it? the it that could be found if he thought of himself more; that was what he had said or she had said, whichever had said that the thing was to be found, as if Adela had said it, Adela in her real self, by no means the self that went with Hugh; no, but the true, the true Adela who was apart and his; for that was the difficulty all the while, that she was truly his, and wouldn't be, but if he thought more of her truly being, and not of her being untruly away, on whatever way, for the way that went away was not the way she truly went, but if they did away with the way she went away, then Hugh could be untrue and she true, then he would know themselves, two, true and two, on the way he was going, and the peace in himself, and the scent of her in him, and the her, meant for him, in him; that was the she he knew, and he must think the more of himself." But this sentence occurs at the great turning point when one of the protagonists, Mr. Wentworth, begins his descent in earnest. As nice as this was in e-book form, I would like to read this one again in text.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I stumbled across this book on an on-line collection of open source books, and this is an example of a hidden treasure made easily accessible by the e-book. Any midshipman at the Naval Academy is familiar with Capt Mahan's name thanks to Mahan Hall, and those who did not sleep through their Naval History course would recognize him as the author of a book that influenced nearly all navies from 1900 until about 1940. This biography was written two years after Capt. Mahan wrote The Influence of Sea Power Upon History. In style, very similar to Samuel Elliot Morrison (I don't know if this was a conscious imitation of Mahan's style by Morrison, or just a reflection of the pre-modern academic style.) It is easily accessible to the layman yet very stimulating to those familiar with the Navy. This would be excellent reading for midshipman, because Capt. Mahan's central concern is not so much to celebrate Farragut's accomplishments as to understand how his development as a naval officer allowed him to achieve greatness when called to duty in the Civil War.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An account of the "Dervish" Rebellion in the Sudan against Egyptian rule, and the joint British / Egyptian operations to re-conquer the Sudan. Of some passing interest as the Sudan has just recently voted to split into two separate countries (north and south).

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Gripping, yet haunting. A novel about Christian missionaries and martyrs in Japan - grapples with the issue of why some give heroic witness to their faith and why simply try to survive. The book offers no answers but hints that Christ remains with both the heroic and the abject..

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Influence of Sea Power Upon History

d:simplesect.d:para: Nearly rates a 5 for interest and style, but realistically, I will not re-read this book except for the first chapter. In fact, the first chapter should be required reading for every Midshipman at Annapolis..

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Between the Water and the Woods

d:simplesect.d:para: Mr. Fermor passed away this year. The day after I read his obituary in the Wall Street Journal, Tom Kalaris (Stacy's brother) sent an e-mail stating that Mr. Fermor was one of his personal heroes. So I found this book at Barnes and Noble and picked it up as a Father's Day present. Mr. Fermor provides a vivid portrait of the lands and people in Austria and Romania in the years immediately before World War II. This book is actually the second in a series of three books describing his trip on foot from Holland to Constantinople following his expulsion from college. (The third volume was not published at the time of his death.) Stylistically, this book is very well crafted, sometimes even spectacular. But the problem with a travelog is that there are plenty of small obstacles overcome, but no resolution of weighty matters that would provide depth..

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stylistically, this borders on dry academic prose, but that may be partly a translation issue. What this book does, and does very well, is to provide an overview of the events in the life of Jesus from Palm Sunday through the Crucifixion, balancing the Church's understanding and interpretation of these events with an examination of scholarly interpretation. If the end result were just a rehash of scholarly opinion, this book would rate a lower score. But Pope Benedict raises our view above the debates of the scholars to remind us of the miracle that has become the very reason for faith and the center point of all of the history of mankind..

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This is one of those classics about which everyone knows a little, but which few have taken the time to actually read. The details of the adventure story are well known; a man shipwrecked on a deserted island who manages to survive for many years alone, the psychological impact of the discovery of a single footprint upon the sand, and the relationship with Friday, whom he rescues from an enemy tribe. Yet just as interesting are Crusoe's musings on man's relationship with God - indeed Crusoe's developing faith can be taken as the key theme of the entire work. This is perhaps, a very Protestant take on theology - a man drawing closer to God through his reading of the Bible and his own prayers and reflections. But aside from some comments about Papists and priest craft, his treatment of Catholics is much better than one would expect from a post-Reformation Englishman. The book is actually quite gripping up to the point of the rescue of Friday. From there on out, it returns to being simply a run-of-the-mill adventure story.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A balanced and readable history of the presidency of James K. Polk. A good introduction, but not a great deal of depth.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A balanced view of the Catholic Church's rite of exorcism. Reads like a really long magazine article.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A collection of "mysteries"; short stories featuring the priest / detective Father Brown. Similar in tone, although both more and less serious that the Sherlock Holmes stories. More serious in that they are more illustrative of the danger of modern life to the soul; yet the stories Chesterton's whimsy and emphasis on Father Brown's humility provides the stores with a much lighter touch than Arthur Conan Doyle achieves with Holmes. (This is not a criticism of Doyle as I love nearly all of the Holmes collection.) Nearly all of these stories were a joy to read..

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Randolph of Roanoke: A Study in Conservatism

d:simplesect.d:para: If you read enough history of the US in the period between 1800 and 1830, you will inevitably encounter the figure of John Randolph of Roanoke, usually presented as an acid tongued curmudgeon with a rapier wit and an irredeemably bad temper. In these accounts, his prime accomplishment was his duel with Henry Clay. Mr. Kirk provides a much more balanced view, presenting Randolph as a champion of individual rights and a Cassandra warning of the dangers of unchecked Federal power. His views can best be summarized, perhaps, by a phrase used by Randolph: "Change is not reform."

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Exploring Reality: The Intertwining of Science and Religion

d:simplesect.d:para: John Polkinghorne is a quantum physicist turned Anglican priest, and this book is a collection of essays on the ways science and religion complement each other. Stylistically, it is rather dry, as one would expect of a physicist, but his knowledge of both the language and methodologies of science and theology give him a very balance point of view that stands against the atheism of some scientists and the anti-scientism of some fundamentalists. Earlier this year, the famous physicist Steven Hawkings wrote an article that asserts that the universe does not need a creator as the law of gravity was sufficient cause in and of itself. He attempted to argue his point in the language of philosophy and addressed some of the proofs for Gods existence addressed by St. Thomas Aquinas. But his arguments were ill-organized and slip-shod. Mr. (Dr. ? Father? I'm not sure of the Anglican honorific) Polkinghorne is able to argue intelligently in both realms and is thus provides a more informed opinion.

Mr. Eban seems to combine pride in Jewish culture with the Enlightenment's (and modern academia's) mistrust of religion. So the result is a pride in Jewish culture without reflection on the status of the Jews as God's chosen people.

d:simplesect.d:para: An e-book downloaded from the Project Gutenberg website. I started reading this last Lent, and finally finished it this year. This is a very difficult book for a modern reader, both in content and in style. To imitate Christ, the author continually emphasizes the rejection of worldly interests, the acceptance of trials and tribulations and the humility to ignore the opinions of others. In the modern world, we are immersed in mass communication enabled by technology, which provides an instant and ever changing propagation of public opinion and which contributes to the idea that all problems can be resolved with the application of time and money. Furthermore, on a personal level, there is a tremendous emphasis on the individual - in terms of health and intellect. So if the author is correct in the path of following Christ, then this book makes for a very tough pill to swallow. Stylistically, the devotional style of the late Middle Ages does not naturally appeal the direct, secular modern style. But, just because the book is hard to read does not mean it is not true..

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Another e-book from Project Gutenberg, and another book that I started in last year's lent and finished this year. The OCR on this book was pretty poor. This is a collection of reflections on religion by Blaise Pascal, and stylistically is much more intellectual than the Imitation of Christ - after all Pascal was a noted mathematician. This book is not really intended to read from front to back, and would really be better read as a real book rather than an e-book..

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I read the first volume of this trilogy when I was in England with Nanny as a boy. Thomas and I have just now finished the whole set - some of it read together and some by ourselves. This was voted the greatest British novel of the 20th century some years ago, prompting much wailing and gnashing of teeth by the literati. For those who equate art with "the shock of the new" (to borrow a book title from Robert Hughes), Tolkien has little to offer. His writing does not offer "realism" in the sense of cynicism, despair, transgression of morals and manners, pseudo Freudian-ism, etc. But, of course, no art is "real", but instead abstract representations that can be good, beautiful and/or true (or that can willfully ignore the good, beautiful and/or true). More than anything else, The Lord of the Rings is beautiful; Tolkien seems to have been a man who deeply loved words. He loves good, old fashioned words and delights in their use. He loves words so much that he even invented languages for the elves and the dwarves, and writes songs and poems in these new languages. What makes this work so enduring and so popular, I think, is that it appeals to our in-born desire for beauty and goodness and shows the world not as it now is, but as it should be. The heroes are not like those we know, but reflect a nobility that we wish we could obtain. The dialog is not like any conversation we would have with our friends or co-workers, but is fluent and true. The plot really could have been taken from any Norse saga, or Greek myth, or German fairy tale. This has allowed the books to be made into a series of very good action movies. As I mentioned, I read the first volume as a young boy, and while the plot did not grip me enough to continue on to the next two volumes, the images of the Shire and of the encroaching darkness of evil and the flight of the hobbits from the Ring Wraiths have long stuck with me. Indeed, the Shire reminds me of nothing so much of Samson's Harbor Farm. What will always draw me back to these books is the beauty of the writing.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: The images are timeless - Gulliver tied down by the Lilliputians, Gulliver in the land of giants, etc. Swift's satire is biting, and sometimes telling even in the modern world - i.e. the ultra-rationalistic residents of the floating island of Laputa. To my taste, however, his satire comes off less humorous and more preachy - more like the crank shouting on the street corner than the wit at a highbrow cocktail party. In this sense, I believe that Robinson Crusoe has aged better than Gulliver's Travels. But the Jonathan Swift's incredible imagination will likely always attract new readers, and really, human nature has not changed so much that his satire won't strike home in any age..

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A monograph on Marlborough's great victory over the French. Actually there wasn't much to the battle. The French line was divided in two with separate commanders. Each of the two French commanders anchored their flanks with nearly all their infantry leaving the center undermanned with their generally inferior cavalry. After futile assaults on the flanks, the cavalry of Marlborough and Eugene smashed through the center and captured the French right wing whose infantry was holed up in the village of Blenheim. The brilliance of Marlborough and Eugene was in the campaign leading up to the battle, moving from the Rhine to the Danube to isolate and destroy a combined French and Bavarian force..

d:simplesect.para: A very readable history of the Greek - Persian wars. Stacy gave this to me as a gift for Christmas; she had read an interview with her brother Tom and he had recommended the book. Probably the best treatment of the Persians that I have read. Does a pretty good job with the who’s and hows and whys of the war between the Greeks and Persians. A couple of nit-picks. Like many contemporary historians, he wants to rectify a traditional viewpoints with regards to the non-Western actors. Like many such attempts, he slips into the trap at times of denigrating the Greeks. But he does not carry this to an obnoxious extreme. Second, he comes across as a cynic in all matters of religion. As a student of politics and military action, he seems to view it as just another tool by which a state maintains order. Third, he can be occasionally crass in terms of treating sexuality. This might be fine in the locker room among adults, but it will definitely prevent me from recommending this to Thomas until he is older. But, all-in-all, an enjoyable and profitable read.

d:simplesect.d:para: His style is very dry and academic, but there are times when Cardinal Newman is very insightful. What struck me most was his descriptions, using source material, of the pagan establishment’s view of the early Christian. This is entirely foreign to the modern reader as our perspective comes about 1600 years following Christianity’s eclipse of paganism. But Christianity was such a radical departure for the Roman establishment that they truly believed that Christians were “atheists”.

d:simplesect.d:para: I had put off reading this as one reviewer had mentioned that it was somewhat lacking in charity to the current popular writers who espouse atheism. But I find this judgment itself to be inaccurate. Mr. Hart certainly does not suffer fools gladly, but in this case, his sharp words are not aimed at the character of his opponents but rather the shallowness of their arguments. Most of the book, rather than consisting of attacks upon atheists is rather a presentation of Christian history and its contributions to the development of the modern world shorn of the current politically correct history of Christianity based upon the distortions of the “Enlightenment”. Also, more fully develops the theme of the utter foreignness of Christianity to the Roman world as discussed above in the "Essay on the Development of Christian Doctrine."

While Sledge says that he wrote the book for his family, it seems that in a way, he was trying to honor the memory of those who died. d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.para: I picked this up for Thomas after he took a field trip to Gettysburg. I had not heard of this book, so I started reading it to see if it would be worthwhile. Given how much I've already read about Gettysburg, I probably would not have looked at it otherwise. But this was such a well written and thought-provoking book that I finished the whole thing. Professor Guelzo offers a compelling narrative of events, he challenges some of the accepted wisdom about the Civil War being the first "modern" conflict, he offers balanced judgements on the actions of key figures and he highlights many of the political aspects of the "Civil" War. Sometimes his supporting evidence does not support his conclusions - for instance he maintains that statistically there was little danger from being hit by the inaccurate fire of inexperienced troops, yet elsewhere he describes an instance of a row of casualties from a North Carolina regiment on the opening day of the battle. But his premise still is worth considering - he contends the mass casualties were a result of inexperience troops standing toe to toe to fire for extended periods, yet not charging with bayonet. This is born out by evidence of units succeeding in seemingly suicidal charges at key points in the battle (the 20th Maine at Little Round Top, the 1st Minnesota at the end of day 2, etc.). This book is a borderline 5, although as much as I enjoyed reading it, I doubt I shall read it again. But I definitely recommend it as first rate military history.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.para: Written in drab academic style, Ms. Faust never-the-less has produced an interesting book on how Americans, both soldier and civilian, both northern and southern, dealt with the enormous loss of life in the Civil War. I can't help but think of William Nevin, who served for 40 days before dying of "camp fever." We posses two letters written by Will to his aunt during his short service that describe the novelty of army life without any reference to the pain and suffering of the war other than a passing mention of a sick tent-mate. When I look at the portrait of his father, Theodore Hugh Nevin, that hangs above my mantle, I wonder about pain he endured at the loss of his oldest son.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.para: We visited Nantucket this summer, and this book was on the shelf of the house that we rented. I managed to get most of the way through the book while on vacation, then checked it out from the library to finish. Ms. Weir covers the back-and-forth struggle between the York and Lancaster branches of the Plantagenet dynasty, beginning with the overthrow of Richard II and concluding with the victory of Edward IV over Henry VI. This era illustrates the weakness of the feudal system - strong kings dying young and young kings unable to keep the nobility in check. In the political vacuum, the struggles between factions in the nobility temporarily weakened the monarchy, but ultimately weakened the lords even more. This set the stage for the strong monarchs of the House of Tudor and the transition to a more absolute monarchy.

There is a second volume that accompanies this, but I could not finish the first volume.

d:simplesect.d:para: A new translation of the unabridged version of the novel. It was originally publishes as The First Circle, and heavily edited to appease Soviet censors. Covers one weekend in the life of a prison dedicated to scientific and engineering projects. A truly magnificent novel, both heart-breaking and uplifting as ordinary people (both inside and outside the prison) try to survive in Stalinist Russia.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Reckoning: The Murder of Christopher Marlowe

d:simplesect.d:para: Mr. Redondi in Galileo Heretic attempts to put himself in 17th century Italy to illustrate to the reader what he feels lead to Galileo’s trial. In contrast, Mr. Nicholl attempts to look back from the 20th century to provide his guess at what exactly led to the death of poet Christopher Marlowe. Extremely well researched, Mr. Nicholl is forced into a great deal of speculation based on a very thin amount of material. In his defense, he does an outstanding job of informing the reader on what he can prove and on what he leaves to speculation. In the end, there is not enough evidence to make a convincing argument, but the book is an excellent introduction to the paranoid “spy vs. spy” atmosphere created by the secret police in Elizabeth I’s reign.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I started this several years ago, ploughing through the sections from the age of enlightenment through WWII. I was lost interest when the book reached the Cold War as I was generally more familiar with the events of this period. Nonetheless, once I started again, I found Mr. Kissinger a very insightful guide to the events that he either observed or participated in first hand. Mr. Kissinger was famous when I was a child; today he seems only to be discussed when someone levels a charge that he is a “war criminal” for some incident or the other in the course of his service. Truth be told, Mr. Kissinger pretty accurately describes the species of frustrated idealist (peculiar to America, and perhaps to the Communist Party) who views foreign policy as a means of advancing their ideals and who treat any rational discussion of national interests as a dastardly betrayal of their ideals. The fact that Kissinger’s critics can only paint him as some kind of devil while he is able to accurately describe this class of critic with an analytic, critical and even somewhat sympathetic eye is evidence that he is much closer to the truth than his opponents. Other critics lay the charge that he is a cynical practitioner of “realpolitik”, but it is clear from this book that he tries to balance the notion of rational national interests with the ideals on which the American republic was founded.

d:title.d:emphasis: The Forgotten Man: A New History of the Great Depression

d:simplesect.d:para: A well written review of the causes of the Great Depression and the attempts to revive the American economy in the 1930’s. The subject of the Depression in general and the New Deal in particular tends to generate polemics based upon an author’s political leanings. While Ms. Shlaes reaches the conclusion that the New Deal did not end the depression and may have prolonged it, she presents both sides of the argument in a balanced fashion. In particular, she focuses on the lives of a number of figures, both famous and obscure, to help illustrate the impact and reactions to the economic and political conditions. I will likely buy this book for Thomas for Christmas.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Third in a series of 5 books in the Game Of Thrones series, although I believe the author is currently working on one additional book to conclude the series. As I’ve mentioned before, he is a first rate story teller - to that I would add that he is a first-rate entertainer. His stories read as if they were movies, which is probably why the Game of Thrones TV series is so popular. So I do not begrudge him his success; indeed I rank his work with that of Tom Clancy who I think was an equally gifted story-teller and entertainer, and perhaps Steven King. But I do have a number of nits to pick. 1. The pace of military operations rivals that of the armies in World War II more so than the medieval era. The speed with which King Baratheon delivered his army from his island base to the far side of the great wall would have exceeded the capabilities of most armies in WWII. 2. While he does a remarkable job of describing a battle, his tendency to resolve them with an unexpected stroke belies the nature of medieval war fare where most battles were resolved by the brute weight (literally, given the armor and horses) of the contending forces. 3. He has obviously embraced the axiom “show, don’t tell”, but he has used the phrase “the juices ran down his chin” far too many times to illustrate the fact that one of his characters was ravenously hungry. 4. The explicit sex scenes are too much - Mr. Martin, to judge by the publicity photos, is a rather over-weight, middle-aged man, and would rather he kept his fantasies entirely to himself. As the kids say these days - TMI (“too much information.”) 5. While he kills of characters in droves, once he narrates a chapter from someone’s first person point of view, it seems like they are in the series for the long haul. In this book, Catlyn (sp?) Stark is murdered, yet she is back from the dead in the book’s coda. 6. There is too much of the “Perils of Pauline” in his handling of Arrya Stark. In fact, at one point I was so annoyed by yet another unexpected turn in her fortunes that I skipped ahead to the end of the book to see how everything turned out. So, over all I can recommend this series, but I don’t foresee the desire to ever read them again.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: A Journey In the Seaboard Slave States, vols. 1 and 2

d:simplesect.d:para: In the 1850’s, Frederick Law Olmsted (future architect of Central Park) travelled across the south writing articles for the New York Daily Times. This was in the time period shortly after the publication of Uncle Tom’s Cabin, and the paper sent him to get a first hand view of the conditions of slaves. He is clearly anti-slavery, but no polemicist. More than anything, he is interested in what makes a farm successful, and his over-riding impression is that slavery was so grossly wasteful that he wondered why anyone would voluntarily continue the practice. He also described the unhealthy social effects of slavery on both the servants and the masters. These two volumes cover his travels from Washington, DC, to Richmond and Norfolk, VA, across North Carolina to coastal South Carolina and Savannah, GA, then to Mobile AL, New Orleans and the Red River district of Louisiana. His detailed descriptions of his travels are an excellent view of life in the antebellum south. The second volume is one of the worst printing jobs I’ve ever seen in a book, at least three different pages are duplicated.

The second half isn’t as interesting as he attempts to draw generalizations on Southern society and on the impact of slavery on both the Southern and National economy.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stacy gave this to me for Christmas, 2016. An excellent history of the Spanish Armada, with particular emphasis on the events that precipitated the campaign. Well written and presents the Spanish point of view with equal attention and sympathy as to the English.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Another Christmas gift from Stacy. This is an outstanding work of military history. The author is a former British Army officer who frequented the Ardennes during his Army career. He turned his interest in his surroundings to excellent use; intermixing many first hand accounts of the battle with his own observations of the ground and his sound professional judgement. I passed this book on to Uncle Steve.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Last Stand of the Tin Can Sailors

d:simplesect.d:para: Yet another Christmas gift from Stacy. A gripping account of the Battle of Leyte Gulf in World War II, focusing on the escort carriers, destroyers and destroyer escorts that confronted the main Japanese force during the second day of the battle. .

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Reminds me very much of James Webb’s “A Country Such as This”, which chronicled the careers of three or four (I forget some of the details) classmates from their graduation from Annapolis though the course of the Cold War. In this case, Mr. Little narrates the careers of two classmates from Yale who join the CIA in the early 50’s through the fall of the Soviet Union. In any case, I don’t necessarily love this plot device; it stretches the imagination too much when characters conveniently find themselves involved in all the key points of a given period of history. But the book was well written and the story kept my interest. One footnote, the book pays careful attention to the career of James Jesus Angleton; although when he exits the stage, Stacy’s father does not get a cameo appearance in the story! (In fact and not fiction, he assumed the role as Deputy Director for Counterintelligence when Angleton was relieved of his duties.)

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A children’s book illustrated by Chris van Allsberg of Polar Express fame. While written for children, Mr. Helprin does not dumb-down his writing. Like most of his novels, he contrasts the beautiful with the ugly, the good with the evil and the true with the false; but he is always more interested in the virtues than the vices. So rather than a castigating the wicked in an excessively moralizing tone, his prose attempts to rise to the perfections of the virtues. I originally bought this for Anna, but she was not interested in the book.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Stacy gave this to me for Christmas. An outstanding biography of a loathsome subject. There aren't many details of Stalin's early life, but Mr. Kotkin provides an in depth presentation of the Russian empire in which Stalin was raised. He gives the best presentation of the system of "autocracy" by which the last Tsars ruled. In the West, we make the mistake of thinking of the Tsars as just another tyrannical king along the lines of Henry VIII of England or Louis XIV of France. But the theory of power to which Nicholas II subscribed was much closer to that of the Byzantine blend of religious and secular authority. (Please note that I do not use the term "Byzantine" in the pejorative sense, but in the actual historical sense.) Nicholas II opposed the radical parties that sought to remake Russia, but he also opposed conservative parties that sought to defend the throne. Any political party at all was a diminution of his power. Kotkin's description of Russia's entanglement in WWI is also top notch. I believe that there will be two more volumes in this biography. I am drawn to Kotkin's scholarship but not anxious to spend more time in Stalin's presence.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Was highly commended in Stephen Kotkin's “Stalin”, but I did not enjoy much. It is a play concerning bumbling provincial officials in a village in Tsarist Russia. They mistake a ne’er-do-well clerk passing through town for a government inspector. Plays are generally not my thing, and you always wonder what gets lost in a translation.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This book was a Christmas gift to Thomas. In grading this book, I’ve gone back and forth between a 4 and a 5. Mr. Swaim is a gifted writer and he has an interesting story to tell about his stint as a speech writer for South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford. Gov. Sanford's personal shortcomings provide plenty of material to work with, but what makes this book so interesting is Mr. Swaim’s attempt to understand why things happened the way the did. One of his most insightful observations is that in today’s world of 24 hour news coverage, the media expects that politicians will have some opinion on any possible subject at any moment in time. Of course, no one can possibly have something intelligent to say on everything, so politicians learn to provide expansive but meaningless answers in order to buy time. (Which is basically the exact opposite approach provided to plebes at the Naval Academy; I was taught that there were only 5 appropriate responses from a plebe: “Aye, Aye, sir” to respond to directions, “Yes, sir”, “No, sir” to answer simple queries, or the correct answer or “I’ll find out, sir” to requests for information.)

d:simplesect.d:para: Bought this at Barnes and Noble, it turns out to be a re-packaging of a number of short pieces by Mr. Solzhenitsyn that have appeared in other books (with the exception of a single new short story.) The writing is great; the grade reflects the lack of new material.

d:simplesect.d:para: The Landmark edition of the Histories of Herodotus is marvelous - tons of foot notes to explain unfamiliar people and places plus maps on every third page.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Mr. Gladwell brings a statisticians eye into the debate between nature vs. nurture in the development of “genius.” While he does provide original insight into some “nurture” factors that are immediately apparent, in the end he offers little more than the recognition that “genius” is a combination of innate capability, hard work and external support (whether that comes from your family, school, neighborhood, etc.) Mr. Gladwell is an enthusiastic and entertaining writer; he doesn’t overwhelm the reader with too many numbers. And I did find his conclusions to be thought provoking. However, keeping in mind the mantra that “correlation does not mean causation”, I don’t think many of his examples conclusively prove the “causation” implied by his thesis.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.para: I don’t think anyone would argue that Grant is the greatest American; indeed many deride him as a “butcher”, a simpleton, incompetent and / or corrupt. But I have always been fascinated by Grant and admired his rise from modest circumstances. After reading this biography, I can say that if he is not the greatest American, he is perhaps the most fascinating. When I was younger, I read most of the books of Bruce Catton and he was a big admirer of Grant’s rise from humble origins and failure to the pinnacle of success. But his work largely ignored Grant’s post war career as general and president and largely ignored his struggles with alcohol. Thomas Buell is one of my favorite biographers, but he characterized Grant as a “yeoman” who achieved success by dogged determination despite a glaring lack of intellect and imagination. And B.H. Liddell Hart proclaims Sherman as the sole military genius of the Civil War with Grant mostly providing support and encouragement. But I think that Mr. Chernow is correct in his assessment of Grant as the true genius behind the successful conclusion of the Civil War. He was consistently aggressive throughout the war; seemingly untroubled by anxiety over what could possibly go wrong yet having an uncanny ability to sense how his opponent’s anxieties could be exploited. His Vicksburg campaign provided the blue print for Sherman’s campaigns in Georgia and the Carolinas. And while the “Overland campaign” against Lee was a bloody slog, he never lost sight of his strategic goal of destroying the Confederate army and Southern morale. Lee matched Grant’s tactical skill, but Grant dictated the pace of action in Virginia while at the same time coordinating action by all Union armies across the entire theater of conflict. While most commentators note the higher number of casualties suffered by the Union during this campaign, in terms of percentages, Grant's Army of the Potomac suffered casualties of 45% while Lee's Army of Northern Virginia (already much smaller to start with) suffered losses of over 50%. And in the end, he had the wisdom to understand how to manage Lee to achieve the surrender of his army rather than its dispersal into guerrilla bands. The coverage of his career as President is also excellent. Grant's presidency is mostly regarded as a failure due to a number of financial scandals by members of his administration. Yet Mr. Chernow highlights the many successes he achieved that have been largely ignored. As much as I’ve read about the Civil War, Mr. Chernow’s biography has demonstrated that I have a glaring lack of knowledge about the Reconstruction era.

d:title.d:emphasis: His Father’s Son: The Life of General Ted Roosevelt, Jr.

d:simplesect.d:para: A Christmas gift from Thomas. An interesting subject for a biography even though Ted Roosevelt, Jr. will always stand in his father’s shadow. Writing style is merely so-so.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I gave this to Thomas for Christmas and read it after he was finished. Mr. Hari’s account of his experiences during the genocide in Darfur in the 2000’s is fairly brief, but as powerful as anything to be found in Solzhenitsyn. Yet for all of the heartbreaking details , he tells his story with a grace, charm and even humor that is spellbinding. Some of the language in this book is as beautiful as any prose I’ve read in English. I don’t know how much of the writing is his own (English is not his native language) or how much is from his co-authors (the title page states “As told to Dennis Michael Burke and Megan M. McKenna ), but my impression on reading it is that Burke and McKenna may have transcribed and organized his words by the style is his own (just a guess.) The end result is both tragic and beautiful.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: I don’t read Mr. Helprin’s work with the expectation of finding the plot or characters drawn from real life. Rather, I will read anything he writes simply for his magnificent style. This book seems to owe its genesis to the real life issue of the recent rise of anti-Semitism in western Europe. It has enough style to worthy a 5, but the plot has some holes that seem to indicate that this book was thrown together in a bit of a hurry. I have no idea if that is the case, but if you approach the book with the expectation of being dazzled by his rumination on art, beauty, modern society, you will not be disappointed.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Light of Christ: An Introduction to Catholicism

d:simplelist.d:member: Author: Father Thomas Joseph White, OP

d:simplesect.d:para: In spite of the title, I don’t consider this is book to be an introduction for the average layperson. In style and content it is more on par with an upper-level undergraduate course. Father White’s style is clear, precise and thorough, which requires close attention from the reader. I picked this up to read during Lent.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A “serviceable” account (ha! ha!) of the abdication, imprisonment and execution of Tsar Nicholas II and his family. Well written, but really sheds no new light on the events covered.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: "All Gaul is divided into three parts;" this book is divided into five works by or about Julius Caesar. First is the Commentaries on the Gallic Wars by Caesar himself, as are the Commentaries on the Civil War. Then come the On the Alexandrian War, On the African War and On the Spanish War. These were written by others, but cover his campaigns that finished the civil war against Pompey and his allies. Caesar's writing is much closer to modern style than Herodotus. The Landmark version of this book is top notch.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Mainly a discussion on how to recognize bias in your own thinking and that of others.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Ms. Chua argues that current political divisions are due more to people's need to belong to a group than to a rational understanding and promotion of policies and values. I have not been registered to a party since 2008, and the longer I am away from my former alignment, the more I can recognize how often someone can rationalize support for a person or a policy simply because it comes from someone who shares the same party. Nothing particularly new or insightful, but a good common sense reminder to at least try to thing for yourself.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A chronicle of the last months of WW II on the eastern front in Europe. Mr. Beevor offers a wealth of detail illustrating the horrific conditions involved in combat between the Soviets and the Germans. I am particularly struck by the similarities between the Nazi and Soviet regimes - in their devotion to their respective ideologies and in their stunning disregard for human life. Before WWII had even started, both regime’s had already demonstrated callous disregard for the lives of their ideological opponents. Their conduct of the war ultimately showed an equal disregard for the lives of their own citizens.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Two Hundred Years Together: A Russo-Jewish History to 1972

d:simplesect.d:para: To my knowledge, this book has not yet been fully translated into English. Amazon did have a partial translation, so I left the grade incomplete. Perhaps the best summary is the final quote offered by Solzhenitsyn before his post script: “I believe that the contact of the Jewish and Slavic souls in Russia was not a coincidence; there was some purpose to it.” Thus this book is Mr. Solzhenitsyn’s reflections upon that purpose.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: The Plantagenets, both the kings and their wives and relatives, are much more interesting than the characters in The Game of Thrones. But Mr. Jones is not in the same league as Mr. Martin as a story-teller. This book covers the high-lights, and touch on some interesting ideas - the development of English law, the evolution of kingship and the nobility, the increasing role of trade and banking. Mr. Jones, to his credit notes these issues, but the format of this book, touching on the highlights and lowlights of each king, leaves little room to explore them in depth.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A good overview of the Spanish Civil War marred by Mr. Beevor’s prejudice for the Republicans. I doubt that anyone in today’s age could be pro-Nationalist (restricting the use of the term Nationalist to describe Franco’s forces). But in failing to treat the Republican abuses of power with the same jaundice eye as the Nationalists damages his credibility as an impartial reporter of the course of the Civil War. To his credit, he is very critical of the lack of political and military capability of the Republicans and he is nearly as hard on the Communists as he is on the Nationalists. He would have been best served to have stuck with presenting the facts and raising questions on alternative courses of action both sides could have taken (which he does quite effectively) and left the moral judgements to the reader. He did this much more effectively in The Fall of Berlin 1945.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A dark comedy of the Soviet era. Mr. Voinovich tells the story of a writer who wins an award of a Fur Hat. But to the writer's chagrin (and ultimate self destruction), his hat isn't one made of the fur of a rabbit, fox or martin. His hat is merely that of the fur of a tabby cat. Vanity of vanities in the workers' paradise of the Soviet Union!

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: This is one of those books that summarizes itself in a long sub-title: The 1% Economy and the Shattering of the All-American Town. An examination of the author’s home town - Lancaster, OH - and the downturn of the local economy due to the loss of manufacturing jobs. The organization of the book is a mess, but the author does have a vivid eye for the people of Lancaster and their struggles.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Tom Kalaris, Stacy’s cousin from Montana, sent us this book. The author, a sports writer, spent a year in Montana following the season of the girl’s high school basketball team in Hardin, Montana. He was drawn to this team because half of the squad were Crow Indians. Having spent a fair amount of time in the west as a child, and having relatives who have lived in Montana, Wyoming and Utah, I was somewhat familiar in an abstract sense of what life was like on the reservations. This book provides a much more detailed examination of life on the Crow reservation and of the complexity of the relationships between the Crow and their neighbors in Hardin. The author was able to learn a great deal about the girls on the team, and in particular of the star player - a Crow girl named Sharon. He learned so much, that as I read the book I wondered whether he was engaging in speculation on what the girls were thinking or feeling or whether he was betraying a great deal of trust of those with whom he lived for that year. In reading articles online, it appears that the second is the case. Before leaving, he had been named an honorary member of the tribe, but after the publication of the book, he is persona non grata among both the Crows and the non-native residents. But while those whose lives are examined in this book may feel betrayed, Mr. Colton has presented the rest of us with an unvarnished look at the struggles the Crows face in adapting to the modern world

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Simply outstanding. In a way, a combination of science fiction and historical fiction. Set far in the future following a nuclear war at the end of the 20th century. Set in a Catholic monastery of a new religious order created to preserve as much learning as possible from the pre-apocalypse civilization, there are sections covering three different periods of history. The first period resembles the Dark Ages, the second with the Renaissance and the final a futuristic modern society.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An examination of the development of the AK-47 assault rifle and its impact in the post Cold War world, expanded with a general examination of the development of automatic weapons and a detailed look at how the US military responded to this development. Not great, but worthwhile read for both those who are interested in guns and for those who does not really understand firearms. In the current debate on gun control and gun violence, the press tends to label any gun that resembles the AK-47 or the M-16 as an assault rifle without understanding the capabilities of the gun in question. Mr. Chivers may not explicitly state it, but this book makes clear that an assault rifle is one that fires a rifle round (as opposed to a pistol round) and that can operate in either a semi-automatic (pull the trigger, fire one bullet) mode or a fully automatic (pull the trigger and bullets fire until you release the trigger) mode. A gun firing a pistol round with the same capability to switch between semi and fully automatic firing is known as a sub-machine gun. Aside from the technical development of assault rifles, he also recognizes the tremendous symbolic impact of the assault rifle. So while the press may be wrong to call an AR-15 or AK-47 that can only fire in semi-automatic mode (the only type of which can legally be purchased) from a technical perspective, they have a better argument from perspective of the public fascination with such fire arms.
