d:title.d:emphasis: Lady of Guadalupe: And the Conquest of Darkness

d:simplesect.d:para: I guess I classify this book as a work of Catholic history. It is not strictly a work of objective history nor a work of theology. It is instead an account of the conquest of Mexico from the viewpoint of a believing Catholic for other Catholics. After reading this book, I would like to learn more about Hernan Cortez.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: A Literary Education and Other Essays

d:simplesect.d:para: Over the past year to year and a half, Mr. Epstein has been a frequent contributor of editorials to the Wall Street Journal and an occasional contributor to First Things. After an essay in First Things in which he discussed the joys of reading, I decide to see what I could find at public library. I found this volume at Little Falls Library. Whether I agree with his arguments (or not) or am interested in his topics (or not), I find that I always enjoy his style and wit. The downside to checking out a collection of essays from the library is that they are better read a bit at a time, but the pressure of the due date forces one to plow through the entire collection all at once. I will attempt to find other collections at second hand so that I may enjoy them at leisure.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The Landmark Thucydides: A Comprehensive Guide to the Peloponnesian War

d:simplesect.d:para: When Thomas returned from the Ionian Village summer camp in Greece, his uncle Tom had recommend that he read this book. Tom had recently read a book called The Thucydides Trap; it is my understanding that this book links the events of the Peloponnesian War with the contemporary competition between the US and China. Not having read the Thucydides Trap and now having read the History of the Peloponnesian War, I can say that I don’t see the connection. I see a much better connection between this book and the events leading up to the American Civil War, or leading up to WWI, or even the current rise of populist movements in Europe and the US. The conflict in this war was an internecine affair - Greek on Greek. They spoke the same language, worshipped the same gods, participated in the same athletic competitions. A sobering illustration of how even in a common culture, selfish interests can override common sense and lead to terrible outcomes. Herodotus, in my opinion, probably offers a better comparison for US / China relations. Herodotus attempted to explore why two different cultures came into conflict, and why the Greeks were able to prevail. Like all of the Landmark versions of classic histories, this book is loaded with maps, footnotes and explanatory appendixes. The Landmark classics almost deserve a grade of 5 based solely on the quality of the production.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An oral autobiography of Clancy Lyall, a d:paratrooper who served in WWII and the Korean War. Ronald Ooms conducted a series of interviews with Mr. Lyall and simply arranged the responses to create a chronological account of his life. Interesting, but would have been much more interesting if someone with a military background would have asked more probing questions about his experiences. Mr. Lyall settled in St. Mary's County, Maryland and my mother gave me this book for Christmas.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: One of Thomas’ textbooks from his college course on the history of Byzantium. Since it is a textbook, it is not surprising that it comes up short in style; especially in comparison to Norwich’s 3 volume history. But it is a very balanced presentation and delves more deeply into economic and social concerns than I red:member from Norwich.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A novella from the point of view of a mother whose son is arrested and imprisoned by the Soviets in the height of the Stalinist purges. While the plot is utterly predictable to anyone familiar with the history of the Soviets, the reactions of the characters to the events is very believable. We have the benefit of looking back with detailed knowledge of what was going on in the Soviet Union. These characters were discovering for themselves the true nature of the Soviet regime.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Another one of Thomas’ text books; a collection of essays on various aspect of life in the Byzantine Empire. Stylistically tending to the dry and scholarly, but each of the essayists seemed more concerned with understanding life from the Byzantine perspective than trying to pigeon hole their subject into modern terms.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Reading for Lent, didn’t finish by Easter. Better to take this book in small chunks than to simply power through. “We have the choice of two identities: the external mask which seems to be real and which lives by a shadowy autonomy for the brief moment of earthly existence, and the hidden, inner person who seems to us to be nothing, but who can give himself eternally to the truth in whom he subsists. It is this inner self that is taken up into the mystery of Christ, by His love, by the Holy Spirit, so that in secret we live 'In Christ.'”

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Zen and the Birds of Appetite

d:simplesect.d:para: A collection of essays on Thomas Merton’s engagement with Buddhism. Gave this to Thomas for Christmas since he was somewhat curious about Buddhism. I am not so curious myself, but still found this worthwhile. "Zen enriches no one. There is no body to be found. The birds may come and circle for a while... but they soon go elsewhere. When they are gone, the 'nothing,' the 'no-body' that was there, suddenly appears. That is Zen. It was there all the time but the scavengers missed it, because it was not their kind of prey."

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: As I get older, I am less and less a fan of the overwrought style of the Romantic period writing. While nominally about a science experiment gone awry, the book is as much about “natural philosophy” and the moral impact of the quest for scientific knowledge.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The War of the Copper Kings

d:simplesect.d:para: A gift from Stacy’s cousin Tom Kalaris, who live is Montana. The story of the development of the mining industry in Butte, Montana. Stylistically, a fine specimen of florid muck-racking journalism. Took a long time to really get going with the book, and this almost merited a lower grade. But the back half was very entertaining, and he remained somewhat even handed in his judgements of some of the main players. The chapter on the election of one of Montana’s Senators is an eye opening coverage of naked political corruption.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:simplelist.d:member: Author: Eric Flint and David Drake

d:simplesect.d:para: Recommended to me by Nick Salafsky. An "alternate" history that imagines forces from the future going back in time to the Byzantine Empire of Justinian I. One force seeks to build in empire based in India to re-direct the course of history, another force enlists general Belisarius in a plot to counter the Indians. The author's try to imagine how the two sides would adapt to the sudden introduction of such technology as stirrups and gun powder. That might have made for a thought provoking work, but Belisarius' diplomatic / espionage journey to India veers way off into James Bond style action adventure. And since the authors' style resembles nothing so much as a Hollywood screen play, it is perhaps inevitable that they imbue Belisarius with a thoroughly modern outlook. But, to their credit, the book provides many interesting details about the external trappings and customs of the Byzantine Empire and ancient Ethiopia and India.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An reflection on the types of snobs, the effects (pros and cons) of snobbery and its impact on culture. Mr. Epstein is a delightful stylist. My favorite touch in this book was on the back cover: blurbs from Henry James, Proust (and one other writer- I don’t red:member which at the moment). These writers are, of course, long dead so Mr. Epstein provided his own blurbs in the voices of writers that he holds in high regard. All the while enjoying the snobbish pleasure of having his book recommended by some of the greatest writers of the past 150 years!

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: Cannon Blasts: Civil War Artillery in the Eastern Armies

d:simplesect.d:para: A comparison of the artillery branches of the Army of the Potomac and the Army of Northern Virginia written by a former US Army artillery officer. His basic premise is that despite the impact on moral of massed artillery, the overall effectiveness of Civil War artillery was quite low. Yet he recognizes the commitment and bravery of those who served in the artillery.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: Given to me by Stacy's cousin Tommy Michael Kalaris. In terms of style, this would be a 1 or a 2. If the writing of the Romantic period can seem overwrought, it has nothing on the muck-raking style of journalism of the early 20th century. Yet the story of the founding of Montana and the development of the mining industry in Butte is very interesting.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: An overview of the development of naval technology as revealed through maritime archaeology. A useful companion to the works of Capt. Alfred Thayer Mahan - while Mahan focused on the development of naval strategy and tactics, Mr. Delgado presents the development of the “tools of the trade.” While the writing is about on par with a typical text book, it does provide a wealth of pictures, drawings and diagrams, and the quality of the paper, print and binding is much higher than most hard-back books produced now days.

d:simplesect.label: review
d:simplesect.d:para: A digitally scanned and OCR’ed (optical character recognition) Fairly poor copy, especially on pages with footnotes. I have had this in my Nook "app" for a number of years and finally got around to finishing it. Provides a fascinating view of Mr. Twain's life growing up and then serving as a steamboat pilot on the Mississippi. Then moves onto a nostalgic tour covering the length of the rive late in life. The reminiscing on his early life is pretty good; the moralizing that comes with his observations on his late trip is sometimes too much. I'm sorry I didn't book mark it, but there was one bit of unintentional irony when he talks about the 19th century being the most "progressive" in history. Mr. Twain had no inkling of present day "progressives" who brand him as a racist miscreant and who would love to consign Huckleberry Finn to the ash heap of history. This raises a couple of points for consideration. When he serves as our observer into a way of life long past, his writing is wonderful. When he steps onto his soapbox to moralize, he writing is dated and laughably out of date. So too, I suppose, will our own efforts be judged by future generations.

d:simplesect.label: review

d:title.d:emphasis: The British Are Coming The War for America, Lexington to Princeton, 1775-1777

d:simplesect.d:para: Nick Salafsky lent me this book. An excellent military history of the first years of the Revolutionary War. He does a good job of also covering the British perspective. An excellent writer, he weaves in a tremendous level of detail from primary sources yet never seems to bog down. Here is my favorite: “Captain George Harris, shot in the head near the redoubt, was saved by trepanning, the boring of a hole in the skull to relieve the pressure from bleeding. Doctors positioned a mirror ‘so as to give me a sight of my own brain,’ he later wrote a cousin. ‘It may convince you and the rest of the world that I have such a thing.’ “ So typically British! The British had huge advantages in training and tactics and command of the sea where and when they chose. The Americans had the advantage of huge distances, a large population and genuine outrage at heavy handed British responses to event in America. Two more volumes to follow!

d:simplesect.d:para: My third time reading this book. Read it the first time in the summer of 1990 after I returned from my exchange program in Leningrad. If you would have asked me then if I would have ever read the book again, I would have said know. While I found the story compelling enough to finish, my feeling at the time was that I had spent too much time in Raskolnikov’s head and that was not a pleasant place to be. A number of years ago, I picked up a recorded version at the library and listened to it during my daily commute. This time, I read it at the same time as Anna, who had to read it for her English class. Just like with The Scarlet Letter, I read it so that we could discuss the book at dinner. This time, the translation was done by Pevear and Volokhonsky. This time around, I found the novel much more interesting. Don’t know if this is because the translation is better, or because I have a deeper understanding of Orthodox Christianity and can see how deeply this influenced the story, or because I was just slow to appreciate the some of the underlying themes. This time, I was also able to recognize some of the reoccurring symbols in the book - such as the color yellow and the contrast between the hot oppressive air of St. Petersburg contrasted by images of fresh air. I wasn’t keeping a book journal in 1990, so I didn’t “grade” the book then. Don’t red:member if I recorded the time I listened to the recording. But upon a third reading, I can confidently say that this is worthy of a “five” as I am quite likely to read it again. Also, while published only 16 years after The Scarlett Letter, Crime and Punishment seems far closer to our current world view. In some ways, Dostoevsky was eerily prescient about the negative consequences of some of the emerging “radical” theories of socialism, nihilism and individualism.

d:title.d:emphasis: Fall and Rise: The Story of 9/11

d:simplesect.d:para: Mom gave this to me for Christmas. Mr. Zuckoff weaves personal narratives following the structure of the events of that day. Some of the accounts were familiar to me from the various 9/11 retrospectives on TV over the years; most were not. I highly recommend this to Thomas (who was too young to red:member the events) and Anna (who was two days from being born on 9/11).

d:simplesect.label: bookOfTheYear
d:simplesect.d:title: Book of the Year
d:simplesect.d:para: Probably Crime and Punishment. I find that I frequently think about Thucydides and his insights on politics and conflict, but not sure that I would actually read the book again. In terms of “style” and the simple pleasures of reading, Joseph Epstein is top notch.
